message: Just a little fun topic. We've all been there: the designer that falls of the face of the Earth, the programmer that just won't see reason, and the money guy that falls out when the going gets tough. Might as well look back an laugh now!
I'm having a poor experience with myself flaking out on myself today. Does that count?
@bat as someone who has gone through the same thing...yes, yes it does
hah. starting a separate topic for that.

I recently parted ways with my programmers after 6 months of development and $20K with little to show for it. I thought I had picked a good team, but I believe they were in over their heads and simply refused to admit it. The instant the & stopped flowing they became complete pricks and ran off. I'm lucky to have my code quite frankly, and to not have ended up in court.
@benwmax wow sorry to hear that. was this a remote deal?
@gazialankus Nope, local. I won't do remote if I can avoid it. This situation would have been even more difficult to deal with had they not been local.
@benwmax depending on where you live, it might make sense to look for a remote contractor who has reliably maintained an open source project

I had a partner who ran up $45K in debt with nothing to show for it. This was about 3 years ago when the solar industry was hot. The guy changed his mind so much it drove me crazy. Lesson learned :: Never debt finance. Always opt for equity.

I have had a problem working in teams where people don't realize that ideas are plenty, its the execution that matters. And if they can't bring anything to the execution, then they should take a back seat and let it be done and pay for it (equity, humility, etc). Some may disagree here.
